I think it's generally intended to be depressive and dysfunctional because deep down, nearly everybody hates living in a city for one reason or another. The great press of stinking, sweating humans forced into as small a space as possible naturally creates conflict that a setting built around it can exploit. From a mechanical sense (gamewise) you can run the whole thing in a relatively small area so you don't have to fuck around with travel rules so much and still have the setting appear large. There's the bonus of the urban jungle effect where it can be especially dangerous and difficult to keep order.

>Are they unrealistic?
In a sense, even the cities we have which are nowhere close to being megacities in the sci-fi style are on the brink of chaos and collapse. It's just what happens when you hit a critical mass of people with too few resources to go around. Unless you're dealing with magical supertech to offset the drawbacks, any megacity would burn itself down long before it looks like the ones you see in sci-fi.

>Do they have a place in your setting?
As the failures they inevitably turned out to be, yes. Expeditions within them are extremely dangerous because it's completely lawless and any governance collapsed generations ago, but the automated systems and upkeep drones keep the city itself somewhat functional and standing.

>Aren't they just an evolution of everything we already know is bad city design irl?
Like I said, they're generally meant to be dysfunctional as fuck. Every portrayal I've ever seen has them be that way, even something that looks shiny on the surface, like Coruscant in Star Wars is often said to be infested with corruption at the highest levels and crime on the lower ones. People naturally want to fuck off to the frontier to get away from stupid shit, and this desire almost always outs in the fiction we create, either by directly appealing to the frontier spirit or stipulating why the not-frontier is really bad.
